awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Understanding the Late Paleozoic Icehouse from a Southern Hemisphere (Paranaì Basin, Brazil) paleo-perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
The late Paleozoic Ice Age is the longest-lived glacial interval of the past half billion years, sharing many parallels with the current icehouse in which humans evolved and live. During the Paleozoic icehouse (340 to 290 million years ago) atmospheric oxygen and carbon levels were anomalous, life moved onto land, the first wooded forests expanded across the Earth, and large-scale wildfires emerged.  Thus, it is important that we develop a more complete understanding of the late Paleozoic Earth and its dynamic glaciation history. The glacial-marine Parana Basin, Brazil provides an ideal opportunity for this work and the project will include training for U.S. and Brazilian students through seminars, field and lab work, and exchange visits.

This research will address three research objectives. First, an exportable, accurate and high-precision chronostratigraphic framework will be built by defining U-Pb zircon ages of unprecedented precision and accuracy for this region. This will permit testing of existing hypotheses of Gondwanan glaciation and will place constraints on the degree of synchronicity of the glaciations and establish the timing of terminal deglaciation in west-central Gondwana. Second, refined depositional and glaciation models will be developed through sedimentologic and detrital zircon provenance studies, integrated into the high-precision chronostratigraphic framework. This will place quantitative constraints on the timing, source, and geographic extent of glaciers feeding into the Parana Basin and permit reconstruction of changes in their glacial mass balance through time. Third, this research will develop U-Pb age-calibrated geochemical proxy records of continental climate variability that will test the hypothesis that major shifts in regional climate occurred in-step with periods of glacier advance/retreat and terminal deglaciation. This project will lead to a more complete understanding of icehouse to greenhouse transitions of the past.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research — Late Paleozoic Glaciation-Climate Dynamics in West-Central Gondwana: Geochronologic, Sedimentologic, and Paleoclimate Insight, Paraná Basin, Brazil

This project investigated late Paleozoic Ice Age (LPIA), the longest-lived glacial interval of the past half billion years, sharing many parallels with the current icehouse in which humans evolved, as well as its subsequent turnover into greenhouse conditions. Our goal was to reconstruct the dynamic glaciation history in a key paleo-mid-to-high-latitude region of the Southern Hemisphere (west-central Gondwana) and to better understand the earth system processes that governed the dynamic glaciation history. To address our goal, we carried out a multi-disciplinary study of 3 glaciated depositional basins in the targeted study area: the Paraná Basin, Brazil; the Kalahari Basin, Namibia; the Karoo Basin, South Africa. Our research focused on several linked research objectives and hypotheses to test that reflect important paradigms in the scientific community or scientific questions that remain unresolved. Our collaborative project involved PIs from 2 American, 2 Brazilian, 1 South African, 1 Austrian, and 1 French universities.

Intellectual Merit: There are multiple outcomes and findings of the award that have impact on the scientific discipline. First, we developed an accurate and high-precision chronostratigraphic framework by developing precise U-Pb ages for over 100 single zircons isolated from glacial diamictitesand glacial/interglacial mudstones in the 3 depositional basins.  This permitted us to successfully correlate the deglaciation sequences across the region and to characterize the geographic and temporal evolution of glacial/deglacial events as well as the nature and timing of terminal deglaciation.  Second, we developed U-Pb detrital zircon geochronologic records that permitted us to reconstruct changes in the far-field sediment flux into catchment areas of the basins in step with ice expansion/contraction, and to document distal sediment sources that substantially shift the prevailing paradigm for continental ice reconstruction in this region during the LPIA. Third, we documented U-shaped valleys in northwestern Namibia that represent intact past fjord-networks that demonstrate that both a large ice sheet and highland glaciers existed over northwestern Namibia at different times during the LPIA and permitted reconstruction of paleo-ice thicknesses and glacial dynamics. Fourth, a proof-of-concept study documented the potential for U-Pb dating of paleosol carbonates, in particular for intervals of successions or regions for which volcanic deposits were lacking. Fifth, we discovered an earliest Permian lycopsid fossil forest, constrained to the terminal deglaciation by a high-precision U-Pb age, that provided a unique opportunity to study the earliest Gondwanan forests and their anatomical morphologies and paleoecological conditions. Lastly, we used Earth System modeling to show major changes in deep-water formation during stepwise deglaciation across west-central Gondwana, delineated by the high-precision U-Pb dating of this project, that would have driven repeated periods of widespread sea-floor anoxia at the time.  In turn, we coupled the ESM results with C and Uranium isotopic data and multicomponent modeling to investigate an abrupt and short-lived (≤300 ka) C perturbation and global warming event linked to an injection of ∼9,000 Gt of organic matter–derived C over ∼300 kyr and to near 20% of global areal extent of seafloor anoxia. Notably, this is the first abrupt C perturbation event documented for an icehouse and indicates that glacial climate states may be more sensitive to climate change than greenhouse periods.

Broader Impacts:  The research supported by this award promoted the publication of 24 peer-reviewed manuscripts, over three dozen published abstracts that shared the findings with peers and students at national and international conferences. To ensure that the data and findings of this research are available to those who are interested, the data from this research have been made available through public access venues and the details of the methodology, samples, tables of all measurements and calculated values, and all statistical evaluations of the data are made available in Supplementary Online Materials associated with each published manuscript.  The findings were shared with broader audiences and the public through sharing the findings of the work in high-enrollment (200 to 400 students) courses at the University of California, Davis, and in public lectures at various venues. This NSF award further supported the education and mentoring of four graduate students at UC Davis, two of whom are first-generation university students and two who are Latino/Latina, 3 early career scientists, and three undergraduate students, two of whom are underrepresented in the geosciences and 1st generation students.  It further supported the training and mentoring of 2 Brazilian Ph.D. students and a Ph.D. student from a co-PIs research group.
